items.reasoning: Both James and 1 Peter open with identical epistolary formula: greeting to dispersed/scattered believers. This is literary convention showing shared apostolic tradition, not merely theological principle.
Both passages command believers to rejoice in trials. This is parallel apostolic instruction about response to suffering, with shared theological grounding about trials producing spiritual maturity.
Both passages teach that testing/trials produce endurance/genuineness of faith. Parallel apostolic instruction with shared theological truth about purpose of suffering.
James 1:5 (ask God for wisdom) parallels Proverbs' teaching about seeking wisdom from God. Both are wisdom literature maxims about obtaining divine wisdom - classic wisdom_parallel.

Both passages give instruction to ask and you will receive. James on asking for wisdom parallels Jesus' Sermon on the Mount instruction about prayer. This is parallel_instruction, not mere thematic echo.
Both passages instruct about believing without doubting in prayer. James echoes Jesus' teaching on faith in prayer - parallel apostolic instruction building on Jesus' words.
Both passages instruct believers to have faith without doubting when praying. James parallels Jesus' teaching on prayer faith from Mark 11.
Both passages use grass/flower withering metaphor for human frailty. James alludes to Psalm's imagery - shared_metaphor is more specific than generic allusion.
Both use withering/fading imagery for transience. James alludes to psalm with shared metaphor of human mortality.
Both James and Peter use grass/flower withering metaphor (both alluding to Isaiah 40:6-7). Shared_metaphor is primary since both employ same imagery.
Both use crown/wreath metaphor for eternal reward. James' 'crown of life' parallels Paul's 'imperishable crown' - shared athletic/victory imagery with theological truth about perseverance.
Both use crown metaphor for eschatological reward. James' 'crown of life' parallels Paul's 'crown of righteousness' - shared imagery with theological principle about perseverance.
James 5:11 elaborates on 1:12's theme of endurance bringing blessing. Same letter, same author developing his teaching on perseverance. Elaboration is accurate.
Both explicitly use 'crown of life' metaphor for faithful endurance unto death. This is shared_metaphor with theological principle, not mere thematic echo.
Both use crown metaphor for reward of perseverance. Revelation's 'hold on to your crown' parallels James' 'crown of life' - shared victory imagery.
Both wisdom passages teach about self-caused trouble/sin. James' wisdom teaching parallels Proverbs' maxim about personal responsibility for folly - classic wisdom_parallel.
Both use 'do not be deceived' formula warning against error. This is literary convention in apostolic writings, not merely theological principle - shared warning formula.
James alludes to Genesis creation account ('Father of lights') to teach about God's unchanging goodness. Indirect reference to heavenly lights from Genesis with theological application.
James' 'Father of lights' may allude to Psalm's language about God creating heavenly lights. Allusion with theological truth about God's unchanging character.
Both teach that God gives good gifts. James echoes Jesus' Sermon on the Mount teaching - parallel instruction about God's generous character, not mere thematic echo.
Both teach about spiritual birth/regeneration by God's will. Shared theological principle about new birth with birth metaphor, stronger than thematic echo.
Both teach regeneration through God's word with birth metaphor. Shared theological principle (new birth) and shared metaphor (birth/begotten imagery).
James' 'quick to hear, slow to speak' parallels Proverbs' wisdom about restraining speech. Both are wisdom maxims about speech control - textbook wisdom_parallel.
James' 'slow to anger' teaching parallels Proverbs' wisdom about gentle response turning away wrath. Both wisdom literature teaching anger control - wisdom_parallel.
James' 'slow to anger' directly parallels Ecclesiastes 7:9 'do not be quickly provoked in your spirit.' Both wisdom sayings about anger control - clear wisdom_parallel.
Both teach about 'word of truth' bringing salvation. Shared theological principle about salvific word with James alluding to Pauline teaching.
Both instruct to 'put off/away' old sinful nature using clothing metaphor. Parallel apostolic instruction with shared putting off/away imagery.
Both command putting away malice/wickedness and receiving God's word. Nearly identical apostolic instruction - clear parallel_instruction between James and Peter.
James' 'doers of the word, not hearers only' parallels Jesus' Sermon teaching that doers, not just hearers/sayers, enter kingdom. James alludes to Jesus' teaching with parallel instruction.
James' 'hearers but not doers deceive themselves' directly alludes to Jesus' parable of foolish man hearing but not doing. Clear allusion with parallel instruction.
Both teach that doers, not hearers, are justified. Shared theological principle with similar literary formula about hearing vs. doing.
Both teach blessing comes from doing/practicing what you know. Practical wisdom principle about knowledge requiring action - wisdom_principle is more specific than thematic echo.
Both describe God's law as bringing freedom/liberty. Shared theological principle about law with shared freedom metaphor.
Both refer to 'law of Christ/liberty.' Shared theological understanding of Christian law, though connection is general.
James 2:12 elaborates on 1:25's 'law of liberty' theme - same author developing his teaching within same letter. Clear elaboration.
Both teach about Christian freedom/liberty properly used. Shared theological principle about nature of freedom in Christ.
James alludes to Deuteronomy's command to care for widows and orphans. Allusion with practical wisdom principle about justice.
Both instruct believers to remain unstained/unspotted by the world. Parallel apostolic instruction with shared theological principle about worldliness.
James' teaching against partiality parallels Proverbs' wisdom saying against showing partiality in judgment. Both wisdom literature condemning favoritism - wisdom_parallel.
Both explicitly call Jesus 'Lord of glory' - distinctive high Christological title. This is christological_parallel, not generic theological principle.
Both instruct against wrong judgment/discrimination. James may allude to Jesus' teaching about judging rightly - parallel instruction, not mere thematic echo.
James directly alludes to Jesus' Beatitude 'blessed are you poor, for yours is the kingdom.' Clear allusion with theological principle about kingdom inheritance.
Both teach that God chose the poor/lowly of world. Shared theological principle about divine election of the humble.
Both discuss bearing Christ's name with honor. Shared theological principle about Christian identity and persecution.
James directly quotes Leviticus 19:18 'love your neighbor as yourself' calling it the 'royal law.' This is quotation, not mere allusion.
James' 'royal law' of loving neighbor alludes to Jesus' Golden Rule and love command. Allusion with theological principle, stronger than thematic echo.
Both teach that love fulfills the law (both quoting Lev 19:18). Shared theological principle about love as law's fulfillment.
Both teach about keeping whole law vs. breaking parts. James may allude to Jesus' Sermon teaching - shared theological principle about law's unity.
Both teach that keeping one commandment obligates keeping entire law. Shared theological principle about law's indivisibility.
James alludes to Decalogue (murder and adultery commands) to illustrate law's unity. Clear allusion with theological principle.
James alludes to Deuteronomy's restatement of murder/adultery commands. Allusion with theological principle about law's unity.
Both reference same commandments (murder, adultery). James alludes to Jesus' citation of Decalogue, though less direct than OT references.
James 2:12 elaborates on 1:25's 'law of liberty' teaching. Same author developing same theme within letter. Clear elaboration.
James' 'mercy triumphs over judgment' alludes to Jesus' parable teaching that those who show no mercy receive no mercy. Allusion with practical wisdom principle.
James' example of hungry/naked person alludes to Jesus' sheep/goats judgment scene. James uses similar scenario to exemplify true faith.
Both instruct that love must be shown in deeds, not just words. Very similar apostolic instruction about faith/love demonstrated through action.
Both teach that genuine faith must express itself through action. Shared theological principle about faith's necessary expression in works.
James 2:20 elaborates on 2:17's teaching that faith without works is dead. Same immediate context, same argument. Clear elaboration.
James 2:26 concludes and elaborates on 2:17's thesis about dead faith. Same argument, final summation. Clear elaboration.
James' 'show me your faith by your works' alludes to Jesus' teaching that tree is known by its fruit. Allusion with practical wisdom principle about visible evidence.
James and Paul appear to contrast on faith/works (though addressing different issues). Contrast in emphasis with shared underlying theological principle about salvation.
James alludes to Shema ('God is one') to show even demons believe monotheism. Clear allusion with theological principle about inadequacy of mere belief.
James uses demons' knowledge of God (exemplified in Gospel accounts of demons recognizing Jesus) to illustrate inadequacy of mere intellectual belief. Exemplification.
Both teach faith must work/express itself actively. Shared theological principle about faith's necessary outworking.
James 2:20 elaborates on 2:14's opening question about faith without works. Same argument developing. Clear elaboration.
James 2:20 restates and elaborates 2:17's thesis. Same immediate context. Clear elaboration.
James 2:26 concludes 2:20's argument. Same discourse. Clear elaboration.
James references Abraham's binding of Isaac as historical example proving faith requires works. Historical_reference with exemplification - Abraham illustrates principle.
James references Abraham's Aqedah to exemplify faith demonstrated by works. Historical reference used as exemplification.
Both authors use Abraham's offering of Isaac to teach about faith. Parallel apostolic instruction using same historical reference.
James directly quotes Genesis 15:6 'Abraham believed God, and it was credited to him as righteousness.' Clear quotation with historical reference.
Both quote Genesis 15:6 about Abraham's faith. Shared theological principle (both quote same text) but different applications. Both quotation secondary.
James references Rahab's hiding of spies as historical example proving faith requires action. Historical reference with exemplification.
James references Rahab's actions from Joshua 2 to exemplify faith demonstrated through works. Historical reference as exemplification.
James references Rahab story (sending spies away) as example of faith with works. Historical reference used as exemplification.
Both James and Hebrews use Rahab as example of faith. Parallel apostolic instruction using same historical reference.
Both teach that faith must express itself through action. Shared theological principle about faith's active nature.
James 2:26 concludes argument begun in 2:14. Final elaboration of opening thesis. Clear elaboration.
James 2:26 restates 2:17 with body/spirit analogy. Final elaboration of earlier statement. Clear elaboration.
James 2:26 provides concluding elaboration to 2:20. Same argument. Clear elaboration.
Both teach that teachers face stricter judgment. This is practical wisdom principle about teaching responsibility, not abstract theological doctrine.
James 3:2 elaborates on 1:4's theme of perfection/maturity. Same letter developing maturity theme. Elaboration.
James 3:2 elaborates on 1:26's teaching about controlling tongue. Same letter, same topic developed. Clear elaboration.
Both use horse/bridle metaphor for control. James may allude to Psalm's imagery - shared_metaphor is primary.
Both wisdom passages use fire metaphor to teach about destructive speech/gossip. Wisdom_parallel with shared fire metaphor.
Both wisdom passages use fire metaphor for destructive speech. James parallels Proverbs' wisdom with shared fire imagery.
James' teaching about tongue corrupting person alludes to Jesus' teaching that words reveal heart and bring judgment. Allusion with theological principle.
James on tongue's defilement alludes to Jesus' teaching about what defiles. Allusion with theological principle, stronger than thematic echo.
James' teaching about tongue coming from evil within alludes to Jesus' teaching that mouth speaks from heart's overflow. Clear allusion.
James alludes to Psalm's serpent tongue imagery ('full of deadly poison'). Allusion with shared snake/poison metaphor.
Both use poison/venom metaphor for destructive speech. Shared_metaphor primary, both may allude to Psalm 140.
James alludes to Genesis creation account ('made in God's likeness/image') to ground ethics of speech. Clear allusion with theological principle.
James alludes to Genesis 5:1's restatement of image of God theme. Allusion with theological principle about human dignity.
Both reference image/likeness of God doctrine. Shared theological principle about imago Dei.
James' teaching that source determines output alludes to Jesus' teaching that tree produces fruit according to its nature. Allusion with wisdom principle.
James 3:13 elaborates on 2:18's 'show me' theme - wisdom shown by deeds as faith shown by works. Same letter, parallel argument structure. Elaboration.
Both warn against jealousy and selfish ambition. Parallel apostolic instruction against same vices.
James 3:15 contrasts with 1:5 - earthly wisdom vs. wisdom from above. Contrast elaborating earlier teaching. Contrast is primary.
James 3:15 contrasts with 1:17 - earthly wisdom vs. gifts from above. Contrast elaborating divine vs. worldly sources.
Both warn that jealousy/envy causes disorder and reveals carnality. Parallel apostolic instruction against jealousy.
Both list jealousy/selfish ambition as works of flesh. Parallel apostolic vice lists - parallel_instruction.
Both describe pure/sincere love without hypocrisy. Parallel apostolic instruction on authentic love.
Both use 'harvest of righteousness/peace' metaphor for spiritual fruit. Shared agricultural metaphor with theological principle.
James' 'harvest of righteousness sown in peace by peacemakers' alludes to Jesus' Beatitude 'blessed are the peacemakers.' Clear allusion with theological principle.
Both use 'fruit/harvest of righteousness' metaphor for spiritual results. Shared agricultural metaphor.
Both teach that hatred/murder violates Christian ethics. Parallel apostolic instruction on murder/hatred.
Both teach about conditions for answered prayer. Parallel apostolic instruction on effective prayer.
Both teach about praying according to God's will. Parallel apostolic instruction on prayer.
James' 'friendship with world is enmity with God' alludes to Jesus' teaching about world hating disciples. Allusion with theological principle.
Both command not to love the world. Very similar apostolic instruction - nearly identical parallel_instruction with theological grounding.
Both teach that Spirit dwells in believers. Shared theological principle about indwelling Spirit.
Both teach that God dwells in believers. Shared theological principle about divine indwelling.
James directly quotes Proverbs 3:34 'God opposes proud but gives grace to humble.' Clear quotation of wisdom saying.
James' humble-exalted theme alludes to Jesus' repeated teaching about humble being exalted. Allusion with wisdom principle.
Both quote Proverbs 3:34 identically and instruct humility. Both quotation with parallel apostolic instruction.
Both instruct about spiritual warfare against devil. Parallel apostolic instruction with shared theological principle.
Both instruct to humble yourself, resist devil who will flee. Very similar parallel apostolic instruction.
James' 'draw near to God' alludes to Psalm's 'nearness to God is my good.' Allusion with theological principle about intimacy with God.
James clearly alludes to Zechariah's 'return to me and I will return to you.' Allusion with parallel instruction (mutual drawing near).
James alludes to Malachi's 'return to me and I will return to you.' Allusion with parallel instruction.
James' 'woe to you who laugh now' alludes to Jesus' Beatitudes contrasting laughter/mourning. Allusion with contrast between worldly and godly responses.
James' teaching about humble being lifted parallels Job's wisdom saying. Wisdom_parallel with allusion.
Both instruct 'humble yourselves before the Lord and he will lift you up.' Nearly identical parallel apostolic instruction.
James' prohibition on judging alludes to Jesus' Sermon command 'do not judge.' Allusion with parallel instruction.
Both warn against slander/gossip. Parallel apostolic instruction against speaking evil.
Both command putting away slander/evil speaking. Parallel apostolic instruction.
James' teaching about God as judge who can destroy alludes to Jesus' teaching about fearing God who can destroy. Allusion with theological principle.
Both teach you have no right to judge since you're under judgment yourself. Parallel apostolic instruction.
Both teach 'who are you to judge another?' Parallel apostolic instruction with theological grounding.
James 5:9 elaborates on 4:12's warning against judging - same letter, same theme developed. Elaboration.
James' 'do not boast about tomorrow' parallels Proverbs 27:1 'do not boast about tomorrow.' Clear wisdom_parallel with allusion.
James' teaching about planning without God alludes to Jesus' parable of rich fool planning future. Allusion with exemplification pattern.
Both warn against arrogant boasting. Parallel apostolic instruction, though connection is general.
James' 'knowing good but not doing it is sin' echoes Jesus' teaching about servant who knows master's will. Wisdom principle with allusion.
James' warning about wealth useless on judgment day parallels Proverbs' wisdom about riches worthless in day of wrath. Wisdom_parallel.
James' warning to rich parallels Proverbs' wisdom about trusting in riches. Wisdom_parallel with allusion.
James' description of corrupted wealth alludes to Jesus' Sermon warning about earthly treasures that moth and rust destroy. Clear allusion.
James alludes to Leviticus' command not to withhold wages. Allusion with parallel instruction (don't defraud laborers).
James alludes to Deuteronomy's command to pay laborers promptly. Clear allusion with parallel instruction.
James' 'cries have reached Lord's ears' alludes to Psalm's language about God hearing prayers. Allusion with theological principle about divine justice.
James alludes to Jeremiah's imagery of fattening for slaughter day. Allusion with shared slaughter metaphor.
James alludes to Jeremiah's slaughter imagery for judgment. Allusion with shared metaphor.
James' warning about rich living in luxury while poor suffer alludes to Jesus' parable of rich man and Lazarus. Allusion with exemplification.
James alludes to Deuteronomy's early and late rains. Allusion with shared agricultural metaphor.
Both use early and late rain metaphor. Shared_metaphor with allusion to prophetic imagery.
Both use early and late rain metaphor for God's blessing. Shared_metaphor with allusion.
Both instruct about nearness of Lord's coming. Parallel apostolic instruction with eschatological theological principle.
Both teach Lord's coming is near. Shared eschatological theological principle.
James' 'Judge stands at door' alludes to Jesus' teaching about Son of Man near 'at the gates.' Allusion with eschatological principle.
Both instruct not to judge before Lord comes. Parallel apostolic instruction with eschatological principle.
James 5:9 elaborates 4:12's teaching against judging. Same letter, same theme. Elaboration.
James references Job's patient endurance as historical example. Historical_reference with exemplification - Job illustrates perseverance.
James references Job's suffering and steadfastness as example. Historical_reference with exemplification.
James references Job's final blessing/restoration as example of Lord's compassion. Historical_reference with exemplification.
James' description of Lord as compassionate and merciful alludes to Psalm's attributes of God. Allusion with theological principle.
James' prohibition on oaths closely parallels Jesus' Sermon instruction about oaths - nearly identical parallel_instruction. James clearly alludes to Jesus' teaching.
Both instruct about singing in worship/response to circumstances. Parallel apostolic instruction.
James references apostolic practice (Mark describes disciples anointing with oil) as basis for instruction. Historical_reference with ritual_practice.
Both teach about healing through faith/prayer. Shared theological principle about divine healing.
James 5:15 elaborates 1:6's teaching on prayer of faith. Same letter developing faith-prayer theme. Elaboration with theological principle.
James' instruction on confessing sins alludes to Jesus' teaching on addressing sin in community. Allusion with parallel instruction.
Both instruct about confessing sins for forgiveness/healing. Parallel apostolic instruction with theological grounding.
James explicitly references Elijah's prayer stopping rain as historical example. Clear historical_reference with exemplification about prayer power.
Both reference same Elijah historical event. Shared historical_reference (both cite 1 Kings).
James references Elijah's prayer bringing rain as historical example of effective prayer. Historical_reference with exemplification.
James' instruction on restoring wandering brother alludes to Jesus' teaching on confronting sinning brother. Allusion with parallel instruction.
James appears to quote or closely allude to Proverbs 10:12 'love covers multitude of sins.' Near-quotation of wisdom saying.
Both quote Proverbs 10:12 about love covering sins. Shared quotation with parallel apostolic instruction about love.
